content: Revised the description in the Input section as it did not specify the input lines of the integer variables numberOfTransitions and numberOfWords.

As part of this discussion about tags cleanup:

https://www.codingame.com/forum/t/learning-tags-cleanup-normalization/186567/5

I'm merging deleting the non-official tag "DFA" as we already have the official one "State Machine". Let me know if you disagree.
Is it explicitly written anywhere (except suggested by the wikipedia link of course) that the given automaton is deterministic (i.e. has at most one transition defined for each (state, letter))?
I've trimmed the empty lines at the end of test 2.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Perfection. Had fun solving it.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I have been waiting so long to approve this puzzle. It's really nice.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good easy puzzle
You should get your puzzle out of WIP status if you want it published :)

Hm , this is is qctually fun to play around .
Cheers.

This looks really tough, but very interesting.
Try to simplify it if there are any ways you can do that? Maybe start with an easy first test case to help people know when they are on the right track?

Also, I think your <<Input>> section is missing a line describing the [[number of transitions]] variable:

{Input
input: the alphabet which can lead to changes in state, separated with space
states: the possible states, separated with space
????? (should say "numberOfTransitions: the number of state transitions")
Next numberOfTransitions lines: The transitions from one state to the next.
startState: state in which you start
endStates: all allowed final states, separated with space
Next numberOfWords lines: all the words which should be tested}

Also the Statement / Goal has a language confusion between "grammar" and "word in language".
To most people grammar is a set of rules for a language that a sequence of words (usually also in that language) should conform to.
Your puzzle is validating whether an input sequence can be parsed by a particular DFA.
In the jargon of DFA the word grammar has another meaning.

Change "status" to "states"; "Coution" to "Caution" or "Warning".
Consider changing [[input]] to [[alphabet]]
"The transitions from one state to the next" should specify the input format e.g. [[S1]] [[edge]] [[S2]] - showing input letter [[edge]] at state [[S1]] causes a transition to [[S2]]
Output should mention [[numberOfWords]] lines
Perhaps change "Since you are lazy but highly motivated" to "Since you are paid per text" :-)

Cool puzzle.
The only thing I would change is that each test case only has one end state. If you don't read carefully, you may be missing out on the fact that there are multiple end states. Then the program passes all test cases, but fails on the validators.
nice

Hey, i liked this puzzle, because we just had to study for it :D. Nice job on the logic, if it is possible (i know, just asking for it never helps xP) try to short it just a little bit. Beginners need the time to get the clue on this puzzle :)

Looks like a nice puzzle once you get what the inputs mean and what you have to do.

For the example given in the description I suggest you provide everything you need to know, directly and explicitly detailed, instead of referring to a validator. It would be much easier to understand and would also deal with the fact that your validator won't be visible once you release your puzzle.
The subject was hard to understand but once done, the code was in fact easy. It was pleasant to do and it learns a new notion. So enjoyable and useful, thank you !
Nice puzzle. Really enjoyed trying it!

I was a bit confused at first as I'm not familiar with state machines.  After a quick glance at the wiki article everything clicked in place. I think the thing that tripped me up at the start was not knowing what exactly you meant by transitions until looking at the wiki. I think adding in a blurb about transitions specifically would help those who don't know anything about state machines (unless you prefer them to just check the wiki). Even something like "State A's transitions are 'a' -> State B, 'b' -> State B , 'c' -> State B. Since our input is 'a', we move to State B" I think would have let me skip checking the wiki link.
Nice practice for reduce function, thanks.

When reading the text and your example in the first place, I did not get immediately where the transitions came from. Either a graph to represent the state machine in the example would be a visual help to understand the example you're stating or if the example was placed after the description of input / output / use case to explain the use case described it would be easy to understand where the transitions came from.
but nice puzzle :D I like it
nice puzzle. im on board

As someone familiar with state machines, I found the code fairly straightforward.
For someone who isn't familiar, I fear the phrase "deterministic finite automaton", followed by mentions of states/transitions in then Input section, could be quite daunting.
I'd suggest adding to the end of the goal, something like "A deterministic finite automaton (aka finite state machine) consumes a string of input symbols (letters of the word being tested). For each input symbol, it transitions to a new state until all input symbols have been consumed.", and maybe a link to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deterministic_finite_automaton

I also think expanding "allowed final states" might help: something like "if the final state is one of [endStates] then the word is valid"?

Minor spelling (several times): "seperated" -> "separated"

Better to use the word space than  " " and the symbol for constraint should be ≤ not ⪕. Might be just me, but just the explanation is a little hard to understand, how about adding a simple example on if a given word is in
 language or not?

Edit: I think a little word rephrase for input will do too.
It should be a simple introduction to state machines and maybe object usage. Hopefully you all understand the explanation and the inputs / outputs / constraints.
Thanks for the feedback. I've added an example, hope it's more understandable now.

Thanks for your feedback. yes it is pretty clear, it should be. Have implemented your suggestions, think with the example it is very clear what should happen here.

Don't want to explain too much or the challenge would be too easy.
thank you, hope you enjoy it

the transitions are already there, that's what I mean by "the language is already built". A diagram would be an idea, but it can also be easily solved using the link to wikipedia.
I have adjusted the text slightly to make it clearer before referring to my example process and placed the link and a bonus tip above. I hope you can find the information more easily and understand it better than before.
I'm glad you like it
Thank you
Thanks for your feedback. I think a picture would be too much help and would spoil the solution too much. I think with the link to the wiki you can already understand very quickly what it is about.
thank you, hope you could solve it.

I thank you. I realize that it is difficult to understand at first, especially if you haven't had anything to do with it before. I am all the more pleased that you understood it and even learned something.
Thanks for your feedback, the first validator is always used as an example of the input. So this would still be visible even after confirmation.
Ohh, you are right. I will change the last test and validator.
you`re right, i changed it

there is a numberOfTransitions in the input

Next numberOfTransitions lines: The transitions from one state to the next.

It says that this number indicates how many transitions follow
actually i thought that you had to wait the days and that you couldn't just change and use the same timer.
my sincere thanks, I am very happy that this puzzle is well received
my sincere thanks, I am very happy that this puzzle is well received
i added it to the "Constraints" section

I've edited the statement based on the comment in the forum ( https://forum.codingame.com/t/community-puzzle-is-that-a-possible-word-ep1/186329/21 ):

Goal
* Formatted "abc", "a", "b", "c" and "true" as {{constants}}.

* Removed "a"/"an" before "a", "b" and "c".

* Removed quotation marks.

Input
* Specified the format of [[transition]]

Output
* Added "<<[[numberOfWords]] lines:>>".

* Formatted "true" and "false" as {{constants}}.

* Removed quotation marks.

Constraints
* Added a constraint on [[sourceState], [[destinationState]], [[startState]] and [[endStates]].

Yes, but you use the variable [[number of transitions]] before you actually have a line saying it is given. It should be the third line of your input section, but instead you skip to the fourth input.
Ok you mean test then, the validators are run when you submit your solution and you can't see them. I would still advise you to make a self contained example, that's easier to understand.

ohh right, the naming was wrong here, I mean the first test of course ... I changed that ... don't think that a separate example is needed, you should understand the inputs better with it. the first test is best suited for this, as the code can be used to check that it is correct

Ok I'll do it for you lazy person :p
Because I insist, look at how many people said they had a hard time understanding the puzzle in the first place. I'm not asking for a separate example, but rather to reformulate the one you already have to be self contained and clearer. See below for my proposition :

Input : "abc"
States : A B
startState : A
endStates : B
Transitions :
A a B
A c B
B b A

You start in state A. The first character found is an 'a'. According to the corresponding transition ( A a B ), you move to state B.

You are now in state B. The next character found is a 'b'. According to the corresponding transition ( B b A ), you move to state A.

Back in state A. The last character found is a 'c'. According to the corresponding transition ( A c B ), you move to state B again.

The word is over, the final state is B. This is in the set of the allowed final states (endStates), so the word "abc" is valid, and you print "true".

i understand what you mean, but all of this information is very easy to collate. Your first area is explained exactly in the input area. It is precisely because of the feedback so far that the explanation is so detailed.

I just don't see any added value in naming all the information twice when there is an area for it? Why should I explain the input again if it is explained in the area provided?

Therefore, I currently see no reason to expand the declaration any further. If I use your explanation there is absolutely no more personal effort necessary to solve the problem.

As you wish, but obfuscated information is definitely not a good practice, especially on puzzles designed to teach people something. Good practice would be the opposite, be crystal clear about the problem then let the concept sink in during solution time.

Unfortunately, too detailed a text can give too precise a description of the solution, which I would actually like to avoid.

I will be happy to take over the process in your declaration, it sounds a lot nicer than mine.
You might be right ... I've adopted your version of the example. hopefully it makes things a little clearer for everyone without pointing too much at the solution.

Thanks for modifying the description, it is much clearer now.
There's a small mistake for startState, it should be placed for state A instead of state B.
Ok you mean test then, the validators are run once you submit your solution and you can't see them. I would still advise you to make a self contained example, that's easier to understand.
your adjustment was exactly what I would have needed to make it easy on my first read. And you're right, the diagram would just be icing on the cake :)
I think the example makes it much clearer :)
thank you, nice to hear :)
